document.title: Empiric Antimicrobial Recommendations for Common Infections in Hospitalized Adults

notes: This document is intended as a guideline only & should NOT replace sound clinical judgement.

trace.sourceText: Negative MRSA nares swab has a >95% negative predictive value for MRSA PNA.
if no microbiologic confirmation of MRSA or PSA, discontinue extended coverage.

when: if no clinical improvement past the expected duration

durationDays.notes: Longer duration may be needed if: Severe CAP, Empyema, Complicated by extra-pulmonary infection.

stopRules.action: Discontinue azithromycin at 3 days regardless of total antibiotic duration

notes: Use Doxycycline IV/PO if contraindication to azithromycin.
ADD Vancomycin IV if: ICU admission, History of MRSA in the last 12months, Suspected lung abscess, empyema, or septic emboli, Influenza/RSV diagnosis in the last 14d.
Preferred if aspiration related empyema or lung abscess suspected.
Use Doxycycline IV/PO if contraindication to azithromycin.
ADD Vancomycin IV if: ICU admission, History of MRSA in the last 12months, Suspected lung abscess, empyema, or septic emboli, Influenza/RSV diagnosis in the last 14d.

trace.sourceText: Ampicillin-sulbactam IV (1st) (preferred if aspiration related empyema or lung abscess suspected) PLUS Azithromycin IV/PO

notes: ADD Metronidazole IV/PO if: Aspiration related empyema or lung abscess suspected.
Use Doxycycline IV/PO if contraindication to azithromycin.
ADD Vancomycin IV if: ICU admission, History of MRSA in the last 12months, Suspected lung abscess, empyema, or septic emboli, Influenza/RSV diagnosis in the last 14d.
ADD Vancomycin IV if: ICU admission, History of MRSA in the last 12months, Suspected lung abscess, empyema, or septic emboli, Influenza/RSV diagnosis in the last 14d.
ADD Aztreonam IV if: ICU admission.
ADD Metronidazole IV/PO If: Aspiration related empyema or lung abscess suspected.

document.title: Empiric Antimicrobial Recommendations for Common Infections in Hospitalized Adults

notes: This document is intended as a guideline only & should NOT replace sound clinical judgement.

trace.sourceText: Negative MRSA nares swab has a >95% negative predictive value for MRSA PNA.
if no microbiologic confirmation of MRSA or PSA, discontinue extended coverage.

pathways.label: CAP with risk factors for MDRO, Hospital-Acquired Pneumonia (HAP), or Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP)

when: if no clinical improvement past the expected duration
if patient has a history of organisms that are resistant to the recommended empiric regimen

durationDays.notes: CAP: 5 days. HAP/VAP: 5-7 days. Ultra short course (≤3 days) can be considered in patients with suspected VAP but minimal and stable ventilator settings (PEEP ≤5 cm H₂O and FiO₂ ≤40%).

stopRules.action: Discontinue azithromycin at 3 days regardless of total antibiotic duration

notes: ADD Azithromycin IV/PO if CAP (Doxycycline IV/PO if contraindication)
ADD vancomycin IV if: HAP/VAP, ICU admission, History of MRSA in the last 12months, Suspected lung abscess, empyema, or septic emboli, Influenza/RSV diagnosis in the last 14d
Preferred in aspiration related empyema or lung abscess suspected

ADD vancomycin IV if: HAP/VAP, ICU admission, History of MRSA in the last 12months, Suspected lung abscess, empyema, or septic emboli, Influenza/RSV diagnosis in the last 14d

oneTimeDose.doseNote: 5mg/kg (IBW) x 1 dose, or 2mg/kg (IBW) if HD or CrCl <20

document.title: Empiric Antimicrobial Recommendations for Common Infections in Hospitalized Adults

notes: This document is intended as a guideline only & should NOT replace sound clinical judgement.

pathways.label: Cystitis with urinary symptoms only (no fever or other systemic signs)

when: if no clinical improvement past the expected duration
if alternative regimen needed

durationDays.notes: Nitrofurantoin: 5 days. TMP/SMX: 3 days. Fosfomycin: 1 day. Cefazolin: 3-5 days. Cephalexin/Cefpodoxime: 5-7 days. In patients with functional or structural GU abnormalities, 7 days of therapy is sufficient in most cases.

notes: Use if preferred regimens are contraindicated.
If unable to take PO.
If unable to take PO.

document.title: Empiric Antimicrobial Recommendations for Common Infections in Hospitalized Adults

notes: This document is intended as a guideline only & should NOT replace sound clinical judgement.

pathways.label: Catheter-associated UTI without sepsis and no evidence of upper tract disease
procedureRecommendations: Remove or replace catheter prior to UA/Ucx collection & initiation of antibiotic therapy whenever feasible

notes: Observation off antibiotic and await culture results.

trace.sourceText: Observation off antibiotic and await culture results.

notes: Observation off antibiotic and await culture results.

trace.sourceText: Observation off antibiotic and await culture results.

pathways.label: Catheter-associated UTI with sepsis and/or with evidence of upper tract disease
procedureRecommendations: Remove or replace catheter prior to UA/Ucx collection & initiation of antibiotic therapy whenever feasible

when: For non-IgE mediated PCN reactions (SJS/DRESS) to discuss carbapenem use.

trace.sourceText:
Consider meropenem IV if:
• History of ESBL E. coli or Klebsiella spp. or other cephalosporin resistant gram-negative organism in the last 12 months
• Septic shock

Consider meropenem IV if:
• History of ESBL E. coli or Klebsiella spp. or other cephalosporin resistant gram-negative organism in the last 12 months
• Septic shock

notes: If history of ESBL E. coli or Klebsiella spp. in the last 12 months or septic shock: For severe IgE mediated PCN reactions, benefit of using carbapenem should be weighed. For non-IgE mediated PCN reactions (SJS/DRESS), discuss with ID.

document.title: Empiric Antimicrobial Recommendations for Common Infections in Hospitalized Adults

notes: This document is intended as a guideline only & should NOT replace sound clinical judgement.

when: if no clinical improvement past the expected duration
in patients who are hemodynamically unstable or have difficult to achieve source control

trace.sourceText: Aztreonam IV (1st) PLUS Metronidazole IV/PO PLUS Vancomycin IV

when: if no clinical improvement past the expected duration
in patients who are hemodynamically unstable or have difficult to achieve source control

Consider anti-fungal therapy (i.e. micafungin) in severe sepsis or septic shock.

document.title: Empiric Antimicrobial Recommendations for Common Infections in Hospitalized Adults

notes: This document is intended as a guideline only & should NOT replace sound clinical judgement.

pathways.label: Diabetic Wound Infection
procedureRecommendations: Patients with NO systemic signs/symptoms of infection & pending biopsy, consider monitor off antibiotic until biopsy.

when: if assistance needed
For SJS/DRESS history with severe PCN allergy, for guidance on gram negative coverage

durationDays.notes: Duration depends on the causative pathogen and clinical scenario. Please consult infectious diseases if assistance needed.

notes: For vancomycin allergy daptomycin IV can be substituted.

trace.sourceText: Mild, no recent antibiotic use: Vancomycin IV

notes: For vancomycin allergy daptomycin IV can be substituted.

trace.sourceText:
If Severe sepsis or septic shock:
Piperacillin-tazobactam IV (1st) PLUS Vancomycin IV

notes: For vancomycin allergy daptomycin IV can be substituted.

trace.sourceText:
All other situations without severe sepsis or septic shock
Ceftriaxone IV (1st) PLUS Vancomycin IV

notes: For vancomycin allergy daptomycin IV can be substituted.

trace.sourceText:
If Severe sepsis or septic shock:
Cefepime IV (1st) PLUS Vancomycin IV PLUS Metronidazole IV/PO

notes: For vancomycin allergy daptomycin IV can be substituted.

trace.sourceText:
All other situations without severe sepsis or septic shock:
Ceftriaxone IV (1st) PLUS Vancomycin IV

notes: If patient with hx of SJS/DRESS: Vancomycin IV (1st) AND CONSULT INFECTIOUS DISEASES for guidance on gram negative coverage.
For vancomycin allergy daptomycin IV can be substituted.

trace.sourceText:
All other situations:
Vancomycin IV (1st) PLUS Aztreonam IV PLUS Metronidazole IV/PO

document.title: Empiric Antimicrobial Recommendations for Common Infections in Hospitalized Adults

notes: This document is intended as a guideline only & should NOT replace sound clinical judgement.

pathways.label: Bite Wound Infection or Prophylaxis
procedureRecommendations: Evaluation for tetanus and/or rabies post-exposure prophylaxis
Consider antibiotic prophylaxis when: Deep wounds (cat bites, Bone or Joint penetration), Wounds of face, hands or genitals, Immunocompromised, asplenia, Wound is adjacent to prosthetic material

when: for all other bite wounds (not human, dog, cat)
if assistance needed for duration

durationDays.notes: Prophylaxis: 3-5 days. Mild infection: 5-7 days. Severe/complicated infection: 7-14 days.

notes: If unable to take oral agent

trace.sourceText:
If unable to take oral agent:
Ampicillin-sulbactam IV

notes: OR TMP/SMX PO OR Levofloxacin PO

trace.sourceText: Metronidazole PO PLUS of the following: Doxycycline PO OR TMP/SMX PO OR Levofloxacin PO

notes: If unable to take oral agent

trace.sourceText:
If unable to take oral agent:
Ceftriaxone IV PLUS Metronidazole IV

notes: OR TMP/SMX PO OR Levofloxacin PO

trace.sourceText: Metronidazole PO PLUS of the following: Doxycycline PO OR TMP/SMX PO OR Levofloxacin PO

notes: If unable to take oral agent. Can also use Levofloxacin IV instead of Doxycycline IV.

trace.sourceText: If unable to take oral agent: Doxycycline IV PLUS Metronidazole IV

document.title: Empiric Antimicrobial Recommendations for Common Infections in Hospitalized Adults

notes: This document is intended as a guideline only & should NOT replace sound clinical judgement.

pathways.label: Community Acquired Meningitis
procedureRecommendations: Consider adding dexamethasone 0.15 mg/kg IV with the first dose administered 10-20 minutes before, or at least concomitant with, the first dose of antimicrobial therapy in adults with suspected or proven pneumococcal meningitis.

when: ID consult highly recommended for the management of meningitis
if assistance needed for duration

durationDays.notes: Duration depends on the causative pathogen and clinical scenario. Please consult infectious diseases if assistance needed.

notes: ADD ampicillin IV for listeria if: >50 years old, History of transplant, HIV and other immunocompromised patient.
For vancomycin allergy: Initiate ceftriaxone as above AND CONSULT INFECTIOUS DISEASES.
Consider acyclovir IV based on clinical presentation and CSF results.
ADD TMP/SMX IV for listeria if: >50 years old, History of transplant, HIV and other immunocompromised patient.
If listeria coverage needed, and TMP/SMX contraindicated: Meropenem IV PLUS Vancomycin IV.
For vancomycin allergy: Initiate ceftriaxone as above AND CONSULT INFECTIOUS DISEASES.
Consider acyclovir IV based on clinical presentation and CSF results.
AND CONSULT INFECTIOUS DISEASES.

trace.sourceText: Patients without hx of SJS/DRESS: Meropenem IV (1st) PLUS Vancomycin IV

notes: ADD TMP/SMX IV for listeria if Ciprofloxacin is used AND CONSULT INFECTIOUS DISEASES.
For vancomycin allergy: Initiate ciprofloxacin as above AND CONSULT INFECTIOUS DISEASES.
Consider acyclovir IV based on clinical presentation and CSF results.

trace.sourceText: Patients with hx of SJS/DRESS: Vancomycin IV (1st) PLUS Ciprofloxacin IV
